title.narrative: Saving lives in Yemen through Emergency Appeal (EA)

description.narrative:
Overall objective: In response Cordaid/ YWBOD will contribute to increased access to basic services including food improving nutritional status of some of the most vulnerable people in Yemen.
Specific Objective: Conflict affected men, women and children in target districts (Sallah and Almaqatrah) in Taiz and Lahj have access to food and hygiene information and items.

We are planning to reach 9,400HH in Sallah - Taiz and Almaqatrah - Lahj. Beneficiary Selection For the survey and selection of beneficiaries, Cordaid/ YWBOD will form the Beneficiary Selection Committee (BSC) composed of Cordaid and YWBOD staff, representatives from local government, community elders and appointed people from the community. A final survey will be conducted door to door using the FSAC tool uploaded to Kobo. Based on agreed vulnerability criteria the most food insecure and vulnerable households will be identified by the committees, according to FSAC targeting and vulnerability criteria. Based on these (household food stocks, current income, poor food consumption scores and use of more than one food-based emergency coping strategy), the most food insecure and vulnerable households will be identified by the BSCs, using the food consumption score card and rCSI.
Additional criteria for beneficiary targeting will be: - Female/ child/ elderly headed HH - HH with chronically ill/ elderly / PLW - Large HH (more than 7 individuals) - HH without any source of income

Yemen is the world's worst humanitarian crisis. According to the extended HRP 2019-2020, 20.1 million people are food insecure, and 10 million of them are in acute need of food assistance. A whopping 25% of the population requires nutritional services to address acute malnutrition. WASH services are limited, with 20.5 million Yemenis in need of safe drinking water, adequate sanitation facilities and hygiene items. People in Yemen are facing a food crises. Two-thirds of all districts in the country are already pre-famine, and one-third face a convergence of multiple acute vulnerabilities. The contested areas are the most affected. According to the October 2020 updated IPC classification over half a million cases of children under 5 years old (CU5), and more than a quarter of a million cases of pregnant and lactating women (PLW), are expected to suffer from acute malnutrition during the course of 2020.

participating-org.narrative: Youth Without Borders Organization for Development

mailing-address.narrative: Grote Marktstraat 45, Den Haag, Zuid Holland, 2511 BH

receiver-org.narrative: Youth Without Borders Organization for Development
Youth Without Borders Organization for Development

title.narrative: WSH-I6: Number of people reached with hygiene promotion/awareness raising activities

description.narrative: Hygiene promotion/awareness raising activities. Could be training, campaigns, radio broadcasts, flyers etc. Excludes the distribution of Hygiene/dignity kits that should be covered under WHS-I1.

title.narrative: WSH-I1: Number of people having regular access to soap to meet hygienic needs

description.narrative: Regular and timely access: 250g soap/p/m for personal hygiene, 200g soap/p/month for laundry. This includes hygiene/dignity kits. Access may be in-kind or though voucher distribution or through unconditional restricted cash to enable beneficiary to buy soap (without compromising access to other basic needs). Distributed items need to be culturally acceptable i.e. take into account local practice and expectations.

title.narrative: Availability of, access to and consumption of food
FSC-I2: Number of people enabled to meet their basic food needs (non-cash)

description.narrative: Basic food needs: assistance, combined with beneficiaries' own resources, to international standard of 2100 kcal per person per day for the period of the action. Any kind of transfer modality (in-kind, voucher, cash) and combination thereof with objective to ensure immediate access to the necessary food commodities. This may include supplementary foods provided alongside general distribution for vulnerable people.

description.narrative: Basic food needs: assistance, combined with beneficiaries' own resources, to international standard of 2100 kcal per person per day for the period of the action.
